content: The example you provided, where our expectations influence our interpretation of ambiguous information, is not necessarily conditioning in the classical sense. Conditioning involves learning associations between stimuli and responses through repeated pairings, often involving rewards or punishments. However, one could argue that our expectations are shaped by previous experiences and conditioning, and that this can influence our perception of reality. So while the example you provided is not a direct example of conditioning, it may be related to the broader idea of learning and how past experiences shape our perception and interpretation of the world around us.
